posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Hello

The old (pre-2020) Command-based framework offered a base class called “TimedCommand” that one could easily override so that a command would automatically end after a given time.

However, the new (aka 2020) Command-based framework does not offer such option and seems to force users to rely on a ParallelRaceGroup to control the time of the command added to it, which does not seem as convenient as TimedCommand was.

Alternatively, the use or subclassing of a WaitCommand is suggested as in this thread Auto Timed command for new 2020 command based framework - Technical / Java - Chief Delphi and WaitCommand (WPILib API 2023.4.2)

But, subclassing WaitCommand is awkward as one has cannot override initialize() or end() without explicitly calling super.initialize() and super.end() since the code that check the internal timer is implemented in those methods (and the documentation makes no mention of it).

So what in your opinion is the “best” way to implement a custom TimeCommand in the new (aka 2020) Command-based framework?

Thanks!

link_counts.title: Auto Timed command for new 2020 command based framework

posts.cooked:
Check out the .withTimeout() method that you can use on a command object.  With that, the workflow would amount to run(() -> code()).withTimeout(1)

I would recommend taking a look at the current WPILib docs for a tutorial on inline command usage as well.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks, that looks like the cleanest option.

I believe though that calling withTimeout() internally generates a ParallelRaceGroup, isn’t it?

Command (WPILib API 2023.4.2)

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
gartaud:

I believe though that calling withTimeout() internally generates a ParallelRaceGroup, isn’t it?

Yes, but this is of negligible cost.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
So what? What’s the problem with there being a composition there?

Composition is extremely powerful, and doesn’t fall to the problems inheritance has (quoting your post):

gartaud:

one has cannot override initialize() or end() without explicitly calling super.initialize() and super.end()

This is why the recommendation now is composition/delegation rather than inheritance, and we’re thinking of marking more of those method final .

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

Yes, but this is of negligible cost.

Good point. Thanks.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Starlight220:

This is why the recommendation now is composition/delegation rather than inheritance, and we’re thinking of marking more of those method final .

OK, makes sense. Going to suggest that doc for WaitCommand be improved in the meantime then Improve description of WaitCommand (API doc) · Issue #2209 · wpilibsuite/frc-docs (github.com)

Thanks!

link_counts.title: Improve description of WaitCommand (API doc) · Issue #2209 · wpilibsuite/frc-docs · GitHub

posts.cooked: I’m thinking more of making those methods final and be done with it.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
That’s an option, but that would be a breaking change.

As a mentor I hate breaking changes because I cannot confidently tell new students how to approach a situation knowing on how it was solved in prior seasons.

It’s a bit of a problem for our team due to Covid-19 as we kind of lost two years of students and the newcomers need time to reach cruise speed.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
gartaud:

As a mentor I hate breaking changes because I cannot confidently tell new students how to approach a situation knowing on how it was solved in prior seasons.

This is how things work out there in industry, though.  The alternative is that everything stays in stasis forever and you drown in technical debt.

Breaking changes suck, but as long as they’re loud and accompanied by clear documentation they’re the right thing to do in a lot of cases.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Indeed, but for comparison purpose, Win32 APIs had no breaking charges in 30 years, and they still work beautifully.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I think the win32 APIs probably had a lot more quality top-down design work done up-front than most features in WPILib.

There are sections of WPILib that are more- and less-stable.  Command-based is pretty volatile right now because there are a lot of people working on it and the best-practices have evolved substantially compared to even a couple years ago.

Breaking subclassing of WaitCommand et al would be a substantial change for a lot of teams and I’m not sure we’re ready for it yet , but I think it should be on the roadmap.  Overriding methods to pass functions is not a great API texture in the year 2023.

Moving teams towards subsystem command factories has the added benefit of making the requirement algebra more likely to do the right thing “out of the box.”

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Thanks for the link to the other thread which I found very interesting. For our team, it’s another vote for “Subclassing Command” at least for the foreseeable future.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
No problem.  One thing I think the WPILib team is fairly good at is making sure that the deprecation cycle for stuff like this is gentle enough that teams usually don’t find themselves suddenly unable to use all of their previous code.

The results of that poll were pretty convincing, to me, that we still have a ways to go until we can become more strictly-opinionated in the direction of inline/functional command definition.  The goal for now is on supporting documentation and example code to try to build familiarity with the new features, which really are better once adopted.
